events.title: Trump purchases The Plaza Hotel
events.description: Trump acquires the historic Plaza Hotel in Manhattan for a record-breaking $407.5 million, at the time the highest price ever paid for a hotel. He financed the purchase almost entirely with borrowed money (around $425 million in loans from a bank consortium led by Citibank), putting up minimal equity of his own. Trump installs his wife Ivana as president of the hotel, promising to restore it to unprecedented luxury. Industry observers criticized the purchase as financially unsound, as the Plaza's cash flow was insufficient to cover even the interest payments on its enormous debt.

moneyFlow.description: The $407.5 million acquisition of The Plaza Hotel represented Trump's largest single real estate purchase to date. The transaction was highly leveraged, with Trump borrowing approximately $425 million from a bank consortium led by Citibank, putting up minimal equity of his own. The purchase price was widely considered excessive, as the property had sold just four years earlier for $287 million. The Plaza's cash flow was insufficient to cover even the interest payments on its enormous debt, making it financially unsustainable from the beginning.

sources.description: 1988: The Year Donald Trump Lost His Mind - POLITICO Magazine
sources.citation: That spring, though, he purchased Manhattan's Plaza Hotel for $407.5 million, a headline-grabbing price that prompted guffaws from real estate watchers who considered it wildly excessive for a property that had sold four years earlier for just $287 million.

events.title: FTC fines Trump $750,000 for Hart-Scott-Rodino Act violations
events.description: The Federal Trade Commission announces that Trump has agreed to pay a $750,000 civil penalty for violating pre-merger notification requirements of the Hart-Scott-Rodino Act. Trump had secretly accumulated substantial stock in Bally Manufacturing and Holiday Corporation through Bear Stearns without filing the legally required disclosures. This represented one of the largest such penalties the FTC had ever imposed and highlighted Trump's pattern of skirting regulatory rules in his business dealings.

moneyFlow.description: This $750,000 civil penalty was one of the largest such fines the FTC had ever imposed at that time. It resulted from Trump's failure to comply with pre-merger notification requirements under the Hart-Scott-Rodino Act when he secretly accumulated substantial stock in Bally Manufacturing and Holiday Corporation through Bear Stearns. The fine highlighted Trump's pattern of skirting regulatory requirements in pursuit of financial gain, in this case attempting to create the appearance of a takeover to influence stock prices.

sources.description: FTC News Release - Trump pays $750,000 civil penalty
sources.citation: The Federal Trade Commission today announced that Trump has agreed to pay a $750,000 civil penalty to settle charges that he violated the notification and waiting requirements of the Hart-Scott-Rodino Act when he acquired stock in two companies.
In the late 1980s Trump became a corporate raider, buying stakes in companies such as airline giant United Airlines and gambling company Bally Manufacturing and then selling them at a profit.

events.title: Trump finalizes deal to acquire the Taj Mahal casino project from Resorts International
events.description: After a protracted battle with media mogul Merv Griffin over Resorts International, Trump strikes a deal to acquire the unfinished Taj Mahal casino project in Atlantic City. The settlement gives Trump control of the massive, over-budget Taj Mahal project, while Griffin takes over Resorts' other assets. The New Jersey Casino Control Commission approves the deal despite expressing concerns about Trump's testimony being "laced with hyperbole, contradictions and generalities." This acquisition gives Trump his third Atlantic City casino, which would ultimately lead to crippling debt.

moneyFlow.description: The acquisition of the unfinished Taj Mahal casino project from Resorts International for approximately $300 million came after a protracted battle with media mogul Merv Griffin. The settlement gave Trump control of the massive, over-budget Taj Mahal project, while Griffin took over Resorts' other assets. This acquisition gave Trump his third Atlantic City casino, which would later be financed with high-interest junk bonds, ultimately leading to unsustainable debt and bankruptcy.

entity-001.name: Donald J. Trump
entity-001.description: Real estate developer, future 45th President of the US. By 1988, was aggressively expanding his real estate and casino empire with highly leveraged deals.

entity-002.name: Ivana Trump (née Zelníčková)
entity-002.description: Donald Trump's first wife. Managed some of his Atlantic City casinos and had input in high-profile acquisitions such as the Plaza Hotel.

entity-027.name: The Trump Organization
entity-027.description: Parent entity for much of Trump's real estate and business holdings. Owned by Donald Trump and used to organize acquisitions and manage assets.

entity-033.name: The Plaza Hotel
entity-033.description: Iconic landmark hotel in Manhattan, built in 1907. Trump purchased it in 1988 for $407.5 million, financed heavily with bank loans.

entity-034.name: Bear Stearns
entity-034.description: Investment bank used by Trump to secretly accumulate stock in companies like Bally Manufacturing without meeting legal disclosure requirements. Collapsed in 2008 financial crisis and was acquired by JPMorgan Chase.

entity-035.name: Bally Manufacturing
entity-035.description: Gaming and amusement company; Trump purchased its stock without the required Hart-Scott-Rodino disclosures.

entity-036.name: Resorts International
entity-036.description: Casino and hospitality company that owned the unfinished Taj Mahal project in Atlantic City. Engaged in a legal battle with Trump and Merv Griffin over ownership. Trump ended up acquiring the Taj Mahal portion in 1988.

entity-037.name: Trump Taj Mahal
entity-037.description: Massive Atlantic City casino project begun by Resorts International. Acquired by Trump in 1988 after a battle with Merv Griffin. Advertised as the world's largest casino upon opening, but saddled with huge debt.
entity-037.notes: Funding was primarily through high-interest junk bonds, leading to debt problems that triggered bankruptcy.

entity-038.name: Merv Griffin
entity-038.description: Television host, actor, media mogul behind successful shows like Wheel of Fortune and Jeopardy!. Engaged in a high-profile legal battle with Trump over Resorts International and the Taj Mahal acquisition in 1988.

entity-044.name: Citibank
entity-044.description: Major American bank that led the consortium that financed Trump's acquisition of The Plaza Hotel in 1988.
entity-044.notes: Citibank led the consortium that provided approximately $425 million in loans for Trump's $407.5 million acquisition of The Plaza Hotel.

entity-045.name: Federal Trade Commission
entity-045.description: United States federal regulatory agency responsible for consumer protection and antitrust enforcement.
entity-045.notes: The FTC imposed a $750,000 civil penalty on Trump in 1988 for violating the Hart-Scott-Rodino Act's pre-merger notification requirements.

entity-046.name: Holiday Corporation
entity-046.description: Parent company of Holiday Inn hotels. Trump secretly accumulated stock in this company through Bear Stearns without filing required disclosures.
entity-046.notes: Trump's undisclosed stock purchases in Holiday Corporation were part of a pattern of corporate raiding behavior that led to FTC penalties.

entity-047.name: New Jersey Casino Control Commission
entity-047.description: State regulatory body responsible for licensing and oversight of Atlantic City casinos.
entity-047.notes: The Commission approved Trump's acquisition of the Taj Mahal despite expressing concerns about his testimony being 'laced with hyperbole, contradictions and generalities.'

relationships.description: Donald Trump acquired and owned The Plaza Hotel after purchasing it for $407.5 million in March 1988.
relationships.notes: Trump's ownership of The Plaza was highly leveraged, with the hotel's cash flow insufficient to cover the debt service. He would later lose the property to creditors as part of his financial restructuring in the early 1990s.

relationships.description: Ivana Trump was appointed president of The Plaza Hotel by her husband Donald after he acquired the property.
relationships.notes: Trump famously paid Ivana a salary of '$1 plus all the dresses she can buy' for her role at The Plaza.

relationships.description: Donald Trump used Bear Stearns as his broker to secretly accumulate stock in companies like Bally Manufacturing and Holiday Corporation.
relationships.notes: Trump's use of Bear Stearns to accumulate stock without filing required disclosures resulted in a significant FTC fine.

relationships.description: Donald Trump secretly accumulated substantial stock in Bally Manufacturing, a gaming company.
relationships.notes: Trump's stock acquisitions were part of a pattern of corporate raiding behavior, often hinting at takeovers to push up stock prices before selling shares at a profit.

relationships.description: Donald Trump acquired ownership of the unfinished Taj Mahal casino project from Resorts International in 1988.
relationships.notes: The acquisition of the Taj Mahal represented Trump's third Atlantic City casino. The property would open in April 1990 and file for bankruptcy just 15 months later.

relationships.description: Merv Griffin acquired Resorts International's assets (except for the Taj Mahal) as part of a settlement with Donald Trump.
relationships.notes: Griffin and Trump engaged in a high-profile battle over Resorts International before reaching this settlement.
